etymologies: early 17th century: from modern Latin schematismus, from Greek skhēmatismos ‘assumption of a certain form’, from skhēma, skhēmat- ‘form’

definitions: the arrangement or presentation of something according to a system or schema

examples.text: one must try to locate the precise questions with which to replace Marx's schematism

shortDefinitions: arrangement or presentation of something according to scheme or schema
